data.body:
The Council can’t just assume what we want when they’re designing parks, hangout spaces, or facilities. A lot of the time, they build stuff that looks cool but doesn’t get used because they never asked us what we actually need. Parks shouldn’t just be about swings and benches—they should have skate parks, basketball courts, or even chill zones with Wi-Fi where we can hang out with our mates. Spaces for music, art, or pop-up events could also bring people together and make the area feel alive. And it’s not just about what’s in the park—it’s about how it feels. Does it have shade? Is it safe? Is it somewhere we’d actually want to be?
The Council could set up an app or website where we can vote on designs, suggest ideas, and even upload sketches or photos of what we think would work. For example, if they’re renovating a park in our area, we should be able to pick from a few design options or suggest something new. They could also run workshops or pop-up booths in schools, malls, or libraries where we can give quick feedback. If we’re involved from the start and can see our ideas being used, we’ll actually feel like the Council is building Auckland with us, not for us.
data.title: Spaces We Actually Use

data.body: School just wasn't for me. It felt like a waste of time, always stuck in one place, learning stuff that didn't seem relevant. I think education needs to be more flexible and practical. We should be able to learn at our own pace, in ways that actually interest us. Maybe more hands-on projects, real-world experiences, and opportunities to connect with people in different industries. If school was more like that, I might have stayed.
data.title: Beyond schools

data.body: School can feel a bit... meh sometimes. I think we need to shake things up! Learning should be like a video game, where you level up and unlock cool new skills. Imagine classes where we build robots, solve real-world problems, or even create our own apps. We need teachers who inspire us, not just lecture us. Let's make learning fun and relevant, so we're ready to take on the future!
data.title: A 13-Year-Old's Take on the Future of Learning

data.body:
The Council should prioritise creating urban spaces that reflect the evolving needs of young people, particularly university students. Public parks and recreational areas shouldn’t be generic—they should be multifunctional, inclusive, and tailored to the activities students value. For instance, incorporating quiet study zones with free Wi-Fi, outdoor seating, and charging stations could make parks more appealing for students who want a break from libraries. Additionally, recreational facilities like basketball courts, yoga spaces, or even open areas for events like markets or music nights would help foster community among young people.
To ensure these spaces meet our needs, the Council should engage students early in the planning process. This could be done through interactive surveys, open design competitions, or focus groups held on campuses. Hosting pop-up consultation events at universities would also allow students to provide real-time feedback on upcoming projects. By making the process transparent and allowing students to track how their input is shaping final decisions, the Council can create spaces that we not only use but also feel proud to have contributed to.
data.title: Design Spaces That Fit Our Needs

data.body: As we navigate an increasingly complex world, traditional education models are falling short. We need a learning revolution that equips us with the skills to thrive in the future. Imagine a future where education is personalized, adaptable, and accessible to all. By blending online and in-person learning, incorporating real-world projects, and fostering critical thinking, we can create a more engaging and effective learning experience. It's time to level up our education system and empower the next generation of innovators and problem-solvers.
data.title: My idea on the future of learning

data.body:
The Council needs to rethink how they communicate with young people, especially university students who are actively shaping their futures. The current approach often feels like it’s designed for older generations, with overly formal reports, inaccessible meetings, and jargon-filled updates. To engage students, the Council should use platforms we already use daily—Instagram, TikTok, LinkedIn, and university-specific portals. They could create concise, visually appealing content, such as infographics that break down key decisions, short videos explaining upcoming projects, and interactive Q&A sessions where we can directly ask questions.
Additionally, the Council should partner with student organisations and clubs to deliver information in spaces where students already engage. For example, hosting panel discussions on campus about how decisions like public transport changes or urban planning will affect us. A regular newsletter tailored to students, with actionable steps on how we can get involved, would also go a long way. By recognising that we are a critical demographic with valuable insights, the Council can build a stronger connection and foster genuine interest in local governance.
data.title: Communicate Like We Matter

data.body:
Introduction

Hey Auckland Council! We young people have big ideas, and we want to be heard. We're the future of this city, and we deserve a say in how it's shaped.

The Problem

Right now, it feels like the Council is talking at us, not with us. Their meetings are boring, their language is confusing, and their plans don't always reflect our needs. We need a change!

The Solution

Let's make the Council more relevant and engaging for young people. Here's how:

Digital First:

Social Media Squad: Create a dedicated social media team to interact with young people on platforms like TikTok, Instagram, and Snapchat.

Interactive Websites: Design user-friendly websites with quizzes, polls, and comment sections to gather feedback.

Livestream Events: Broadcast council meetings and public consultations live on platforms like Twitch or YouTube.

Youth Advisory Boards:

Empower Young Voices: Establish youth advisory boards to provide direct input on council decisions.

Diverse Representation: Ensure that these boards represent a wide range of backgrounds and perspectives.

Gamify the Process:

City-Building Simulations: Develop online games where young people can design and plan their ideal city.

Challenge Competitions: Host competitions for young people to come up with innovative solutions to urban challenges.

Youth-Friendly Language:

Simple and Clear: Use plain language and avoid jargon in all communications.

Visual Appeal: Incorporate visuals, memes, and short videos to make information more engaging.

Conclusion

By embracing these ideas, the Council can create a more inclusive and youth-friendly environment. Let's work together to build a better Auckland for everyone.

Call to Action:

Follow us on social media for updates and to share your ideas.

Join our online forums to discuss issues and propose solutions.

Contact your local councilor to express your concerns and suggestions.

Let's make our voices heard and shape the future of Auckland!
data.title: Tune In, Turn Up: Making Council Cool Again"

data.body:
It’s one thing to tell us what’s happening in Auckland, but it’s a whole other thing to give us real power to make decisions. Young people need a proper seat at the table, not just a token invite to meetings that are already planned without us. The Council should set up youth committees or councils where teenagers from different schools, communities, and backgrounds can represent their areas. These groups could meet regularly, pitch ideas, and vote on things that directly affect us—like public transport, parks, and events.
The meetings shouldn’t feel stiff and corporate either. Hold them at places we like, like cafes, libraries, or community hubs, and make the environment welcoming. And let’s be real: if you want teens to show up and take it seriously, you need to give us some incentives. Free food, free transport to the meetings, and even small payments for our time would show us that you value our input. To make it even more impactful, let us see the results of our ideas—whether that’s a new basketball court at a park or an event that we helped organise. When we see our voices actually making a difference, we’ll feel like we’re part of the change.
data.title: Give Us a Seat at the Table

data.body:
If the Council wants to connect with young people, they’ve got to stop talking at us and start talking with us. Formal emails and boring brochures don’t grab our attention—we’re scrolling TikTok, snapping our friends, and watching YouTube. The Council should use platforms we’re already on, like Instagram, TikTok, or even Discord, to share updates about projects and plans. They could make short, funny videos, use memes that make us laugh, and throw in polls or quizzes we can answer in a click. Imagine a TikTok that explains why a new park is being built or why we need more bike lanes—it could be funny, relatable, and quick to watch.
To really get our attention, they should collaborate with local influencers who we already follow. These people could help explain Council stuff in a way that doesn’t sound like a boring lecture. Plus, the Council should ask us directly what kind of content we like to see, maybe through a social media challenge where we share ideas and get prizes for the best suggestions. Talk like we do, make it engaging, and we’ll actually care about what’s happening in our city.
data.title: Talk Like We Do

data.body:
What if every day at school felt like an exciting adventure? Instead of sitting at our desks and listening to the teacher, we could be solving mysteries, exploring virtual worlds, or creating things that are actually useful. For example, imagine learning about space by designing and building our own rocket ships and launching them in the schoolyard. In history class, we could reenact important events or do scavenger hunts to uncover clues about how people lived in the past. Science could be all about experiments, like creating potions or growing plants in a mini greenhouse.
Teachers could make each subject feel like a new mission for us to complete, turning lessons into fun challenges where we learn by doing. They could even let us pick what kind of “adventure” we want to take part in each week, giving us more say in how we learn. If schools asked for our input on what activities would make learning fun and creative, we’d all be way more excited to show up every day. Learning through adventures wouldn’t just be more engaging; it’d help us remember what we learn because we’d be experiencing it firsthand.
data.title: Learning Through Adventures

data.body:
Classrooms right now are kind of boring. Most of them look the same—rows of desks, plain walls, and a teacher standing at the front. What if schools had really cool spaces that made learning fun and exciting? Imagine a science lab where you could wear VR headsets and take a virtual tour of the solar system or explore inside the human body. For art, there could be huge walls where we’re allowed to paint and draw anything we want, or digital tablets to make cool animations. Outdoor classrooms could be used for subjects like biology, where we learn about plants and animals by observing them in real life.
Even small changes would make a big difference, like having comfy chairs, colourful walls, or places to sit in groups. Libraries could have gaming zones with educational games, and computer labs could have spaces where we learn coding by building robots or apps. If schools made these spaces less like offices and more like creative zones, we’d be excited to spend time there. Plus, they could ask us what kind of spaces we’d like and let us help design them so that they really feel like they’re made for us.
data.title: Cool Spaces for Cool Learning

data.body:
Classes would be so much more exciting if we could actually get our hands dirty and create things instead of just listening and taking notes. For example, in science, instead of reading about how ecosystems work, we could build our own mini ecosystems in a jar and see how plants, animals, and bacteria interact over time. In history, we could create projects like making a documentary about a historical event or building models of ancient cities. English class could involve writing scripts for short films or acting out scenes from books we’re studying.
Teachers could also use technology to make lessons more interactive. Imagine using virtual reality to walk through ancient Rome or simulate a chemistry lab experiment without worrying about breaking stuff. Even group projects where we collaborate to solve a problem or build something together would make school more fun and teach us teamwork. If every class had at least one hands-on activity each week, learning would feel less like a chore and more like something we look forward to.
data.title: Make Classes Hands-On and Creative

data.body:
One of the most important changes schools could make is letting students have a bigger say in how learning happens. Right now, it feels like we’re just expected to go along with whatever teachers and administrators decide. What if we had regular student meetings where we could share our thoughts about what’s working and what’s not? For example, we could suggest more outdoor classes, fewer tests, or more chances to learn through projects instead of lectures. Teachers could use this feedback to try out new ideas and see what works best for us.
Schools could also let us lead our own learning experiences. For example, we could run clubs or workshops where students teach each other about things we’re passionate about, like coding, cooking, or filmmaking. There could even be “student choice days” where we design our own schedules based on the activities and subjects we find most interesting. If schools gave us more freedom to shape our education and actually listened to our ideas, we’d feel more motivated to engage and succeed. It’s all about making learning something we do with our schools, not something that’s done to us.
data.title: Let Students Lead the Way

data.body:
Education becomes so much more exciting when it’s connected to real-world challenges and solutions. Universities should focus on creating opportunities for students to work on practical projects that tackle big issues in our communities or industries. For example, engineering students could work on sustainable housing designs for areas facing a housing crisis, while environmental science students collaborate with local councils to create strategies for reducing pollution. Business and communications students could design campaigns to promote these projects, creating an interdisciplinary approach that mirrors how things work in the real world.
These projects could be tied to internships or competitions where the best ideas are implemented. Universities should also connect students with professionals from different industries through guest lectures, mentorship programs, or collaborative workshops. This would allow us to learn directly from people working in the fields we’re studying, giving us a clearer idea of how our education applies to our future careers. If universities make learning more practical and show us the direct impact of what we’re working on, it would be both engaging and incredibly rewarding.
data.title: Education for the Real World

data.body:
I'm 13 years old, and I live in Auckland. It's a pretty cool city, but I think it could be even better. The problem is, adults seem to be the only ones making decisions about our city. They don't always get it right.

I wish the council would talk to us, the young people. We have ideas, you know. We live here too! They could start by using social media more. TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube – that's where we are. They could post videos about what's going on, ask us questions, and run polls.

We could have online forums or even video game worlds where we can discuss issues and come up with solutions. It would be awesome to have a virtual city where we can design our dream Auckland.

Another idea is to have youth councils. We could elect representatives from schools and communities to work with the actual council. We could give them our ideas and help them make decisions that affect us.

It's not just about talking to us, though. The council needs to listen to us. They should take our ideas seriously and consider them when they're planning things. We want to be part of shaping our city's future, not just watching from the sidelines.

So, let's make our voices heard! Let's show the council that young people care about our city and want to be involved.
data.title: My City, My Say

data.body:
One of the biggest ways universities could make learning more enjoyable is by offering flexibility and personalisation in how we learn. Right now, most courses follow a one-size-fits-all approach, with rigid schedules and teaching methods. Instead, universities could offer modular courses where we pick and choose the topics we’re most interested in, allowing us to create a more personalised learning journey. For example, a student studying computer science could focus more on AI or cybersecurity, while someone in business studies could dive deeper into social entrepreneurship or digital marketing.
Flexibility should also extend to how classes are delivered. Universities could offer hybrid models where students can attend lectures in person, online, or even watch recordings later. This would make it easier for students balancing work, family, or other commitments. Finally, schools need to adapt teaching methods based on student feedback. Regular surveys or forums could give students a chance to voice their preferences, like wanting more hands-on projects or interactive lessons. By giving us more control over what and how we learn, universities would create an environment where students feel supported and motivated to succeed.
data.title: Flexible and Personalised Education

data.body:
I can't imagine a world where education is exciting and learning is fun. It sounds like a dream, a world far removed from the monotonous routine of textbooks, lectures, and endless tests. In my world, school is a chore, a place where my curiosity is stifled and my potential is untapped.

I long for a classroom where learning isn't confined to the four walls of a room. Imagine field trips to museums, interactive workshops with real-world experts, and even virtual reality experiences that transport us to ancient civilizations or distant galaxies. Instead of memorizing dates and reciting facts, we could explore the world through hands-on projects and collaborative problem-solving.

I yearn for teachers who inspire, not just instruct. Teachers who see the spark in our eyes and fuel it with passion. Teachers who listen to our ideas, value our opinions, and encourage us to think critically. Imagine a classroom where our voices are heard, where our questions are welcomed, and where our creativity is nurtured.

I believe that technology can revolutionize education. Imagine interactive textbooks that adapt to our learning styles, personalized learning plans tailored to our individual needs, and online platforms that connect us with students and experts from around the globe. With the right tools and resources, we can transform education into an exciting and engaging experience.

But it's not just about technology. It's about fostering a love of learning, a sense of curiosity, and a desire to make a difference. It's about creating a supportive and inclusive environment where everyone feels valued and empowered.

I believe that schools have a responsibility to listen to our voices. We are the future, and our ideas matter. By involving us in the decision-making process, we can create a more relevant and engaging education system.

Let's work together to build a world where education is exciting and learning is fun. A world where we are inspired, empowered, and ready to shape the future.
data.title: Beyond the Textbook

data.body:
University students are at a stage where we’re developing ideas, finding our voices, and building a sense of civic responsibility. To truly engage us, the Council needs to move beyond consultation and provide opportunities for us to actively shape decisions. Setting up youth advisory panels specifically for students could be an effective start. These panels should focus on issues that resonate with us, such as affordable housing, sustainability initiatives, and public transport improvements.
But it’s not just about setting up panels—it’s about giving these groups real power and resources to make meaningful contributions. Members could participate in workshops with Council officials, co-design projects, and even review policies that affect young people. Incentives like stipends, certificates of recognition, or internship opportunities with the Council would encourage participation. Students are motivated by seeing tangible outcomes; if we know our voices are shaping policies or projects that affect us, we’ll be more likely to engage and spread the word within our networks.
data.title: Integrate Us into the Decision-Making Process

data.body:
I stand before you today, not just as a young person, but as a future leader, a future taxpayer, and a future resident of this great city. I’m here to speak about a future that's shaped by us, not just for us.

We, the youth of Auckland, are often overlooked in the grand scheme of city planning. We’re told our voices don’t matter, that we’re too young to understand the complexities of urban development. But I say, we’re the ones who will inherit this city. We deserve a say in its future.

The council needs to step up its game. It's time to move beyond outdated methods of engagement. We need innovative solutions that resonate with our generation. Let's see more social media campaigns, interactive online platforms, and youth-focused workshops.

We need to be more than just passive recipients of information. We want to be active participants in shaping our city. Imagine a youth advisory board, where young people can directly influence council decisions. Or perhaps a youth-led design competition to revitalize public spaces.

The council should also prioritize projects that cater to our needs. More affordable housing, better public transport, and increased investment in mental health services are just a few examples.

Let’s make Auckland a city that truly embraces its young people. A city where our voices are heard, our ideas are valued, and our future is secured. It’s time to turn the page and write a new chapter in Auckland’s story, one that's written by all of us.
data.title: A Future for Us, By Us

data.body:
Many students are searching for ways to make their academic studies impactful in the real world. The Council could form partnerships with universities to turn student projects into practical solutions for Auckland’s challenges. For example, urban planning students could design solutions for overcrowded housing, while environmental science students work on proposals for improving green spaces or managing stormwater.
These partnerships could be facilitated through Council-sponsored research grants, internships, or final-year projects directly tied to Council initiatives. By aligning academic work with real-world issues, students gain practical experience, and the Council benefits from innovative, research-driven solutions. Additionally, hosting an annual showcase for student-led solutions would be a great way to foster excitement and visibility, while demonstrating the Council’s commitment to supporting young people’s ideas.
data.title: Bridging the Gap: Real-World Impact Through Council Partnerships

data.body:
University students represent the future of Auckland, and our perspectives are crucial in shaping long-term projects. To truly engage us, the Council should prioritise collaboration over consultation. Instead of presenting pre-made plans for Auckland's future, why not co-create them with us? For instance, a "City of Tomorrow" competition could invite students to submit ideas for urban design, sustainable housing, or community spaces, with the winning concepts integrated into real projects.
Workshops and hackathons could also be held at universities, allowing students to collaborate with city planners, architects, and policy-makers. This hands-on involvement would not only spark innovative ideas but also help students understand the complexities of urban planning. By creating avenues for students to contribute meaningfully to projects like climate adaptation strategies, public transport expansion, or green infrastructure, the Council can tap into fresh perspectives while fostering a generation of civic-minded leaders.
data.title: Auckland 2040: Co-Creating the Vision

data.body:
Public engagement often feels one-sided, with the Council presenting ideas and expecting feedback, but not truly inviting collaboration. This dynamic needs to change, particularly for students who are passionate about social justice, environmental sustainability, and urban equity. A participatory budget programme could allow students to directly decide how a portion of Council funds is spent in their communities.
This initiative could work by hosting brainstorming sessions on campuses, where students propose and vote on ideas such as new bike lanes, better lighting for safety, or art installations in public spaces. The Council could allocate a set amount of funding for these student-driven initiatives, ensuring that young people see their priorities reflected in tangible outcomes. This approach not only makes governance more accessible but also empowers students to feel like active contributors to their city’s development
data.title: Rewriting Public Engagement: From Passive to Participatory
